idea:
A journey started by two enterprising sisters, Sujata and Taniya Biswas believes Suta isn’t just an entrepreneurial stint for them it is an ever-growing family that celebrates sustainable with fashion. Each piece is designed from the heart combining India’s centuries-old weaving traditions contemporary style.

Labour of Love:

City girls but traditionalist at heart Su and Ta often found it difficult to source affordable, sustainable and contemporary Indian wear for themselves. What gave them the nudge to pause and give up the everyday bustle and jump the entrepreneurial band wagon, was a trip to their native village in West Bengal. Fascinated with the weaving craft and appalled at the current conditions, they took it on themselves to revitalize this unique handloom industry. Their business aim was simple: to uplift the weaver community, to promote slow fashion and to bring back the saree as an everyday uber cool outfit for all generations at affordable prices. Today, as they look back with pride, they are a strong team of weavers, designers, embroiderers and admin, weaving the future together as a Rs. 6 crore bootstrapped company!

Today, though the handloom industry constitutes one of the most extensive and dynamic facets of Indian cultural heritage, the industry is dying a slow death due to absence of aid, deskilled labour and an influx of fast fashion. Most workers whom Sujata and Taniya interacted with were being forced to leave their skilled jobs for better paying jobs in larger cities but as vendors or construction workers or something equally heart-crushing. SuTa’s main mission began with the philosophy to change the way handcrafted textiles in India were sold and presented – with a strong focus on getting the weavers and craftsmen back into action!

“As we studied the market, we realised that there are three things required for creating an impact for the revival of handlooms–design, intervention and innovation by designers. We helped our weavers evolve, mix and match yarns and reinterpret traditional designs into newer and more modern versions – so that we could appeal to and cultivate a larger audience” explains Sujata
name: Suta
